CustomField.description: Outcomes from the Sport NZ intervention logics
CustomField.inlineHelpText: Select the outcomes you are working towards from the Sport NZ intervention logics
CustomField.label: Outcomes

valueSettings.valueName: Partners understand, lead and advocate for quality opportunities for tamariki and rangatahi, targeting less active and teenage drop off, through Play, Active Recreation, Sport and PE​
Partners contribute to the development of other regional/national/hapu/iwi strategies and plans​
Partners leading and advocating for the inclusion of (kaupapa) Maori approaches to Play, Active Recreation and sport.​
Partners leading and advocating for diversity and inclusion​
Partners embedding the three approaches (internally and externally)​
Partners lead workforce/people planning and development​
Partners facilitate and host networking / hosting / hui opportunities​
RSTs prioritise quality opportunities for tamariki in their region through healthy active learning​
RSTs have an aligned and integrated approach to supporting quality opportunities for tamariki and rangatahi (using healthy active learning as a foundation)​
RSTs understand the networks and organisations in their region who deliver opportunities to tamariki and rangatahi ​
RSTs have appropriate capacity and sufficient capability, to influence quality opportunities for tamariki in their region aligned with healthy active learning​
Organisations understand the value of physical activity for tamariki and rangatahi​
Cultural understanding is embedded within an organisation​
Diversity and inclusion is embedded within an organisation​
Better informed and regionally/nationally connected network of organisations​
Regional agencies understand the value of Healthy Active Learning and its importance in the delivery of Play, Active Recreation, Sport and PE for tamariki​
Communities work in collaboration for the delivery of quality opportunities for tamariki and rangatahi​
Improved demonstration of the principles of Te Tiriti o Waitangi​
Strong regional and national leadership and advocacy for physical activity​
Better decision-making to inform strategies for tamariki and rangatahi​
Regional agencies adopt aligned approaches for the delivery of quality opportunities for tamariki and rangatahi​
Improved access to external support ​
Improved access to tools and resources​
Improved quality of training and development opportunities​
Improved understanding of the benefits of intelligence​
Improved identification of key stakeholders requiring evidence​
Improved definition of information needs (e.g research questions)​
Improved information collection and analytical skills​
Improved information interpretation and translational skills ​
Improved infrastructure to collect and analyse information (e.g. tools, storage, linking to other data sources)​
Improved protocols to collect and analyse information (e.g. consent, confidentiality)​
Improved leadership and internal advocacy for intelligence​
Leaders enable the use of intelligence throughout the organisation​
Improved allocation of time and resource to intelligence​
Improved tailoring for and sharing of information with key stakeholders (e.g. through presentation, meetings, resources)​
Improved competency of organisation in intelligence (i.e. research, evaluation, insights)​
Improved systems to support use of evidence ​
Improved intelligence climate provided by leadership ​
Improved communication with internal, local, regional and national stakeholders​
Improved evidence-based decision making ​
Improved advocacy through use of evidence (i.e. influencing others)​
Tools, resources and guidelines are developed in collaboration with the sector to meet their needs and build capability​
RSTs and TAs advocate for the protection and enhancement of built and natural environments that promote play, active recreation and sport​
Key funders support National and Regional Planning Approaches and priority projects​
RSTs lead development, review, and implementation of regional plans​
NSOs and NROs lead development of planning approach for International, National and Regional Spaces & Places provision​
Key stakeholders partner to respond to ‘whole of community’ Spaces & Places needs​
National Spaces & Places database and planning tool are delivered and enhanced to support improved planning​
Key organisations work together to identify settings and connections for the Spaces & Places network
Minimum quality standards for the setting and environment for play and physical activity settings in schools are developed​
Territorial Authorities’ Annual and Long-Term Plans reflect regional Spaces & Places priority projects​
Key funders direct their financial support towards regional Spaces & Places priority projects​
Key stakeholders work together to identify national, regional and local spaces and places principles, processes and priorities​
RSTs support organisations and clubs to navigate through the Spaces & Places planning process​
The right type and location of Spaces & Places are identified and developed ​
Spaces & Places are managed and operated efficiently and effectively to enable resources to focus on delivering physical activity​
RSTs lead communities to work in partnership for the planning, development, provision and operation of Spaces & Places​
Spaces & Places meet the needs of the communities they serve, ​
Spaces & Places are utilised to their full potential​
Spaces & Places are fully accessible​
Spaces & Places are multi-use, flexible and sustainable​
Enablers have effective systems in place at national, regional and local levels to engage, educate and support parents and peers​
Enablers demonstrate their knowledge and understanding of the value of Play through messaging, actions and social or physical infrastructure​
National, regional and local enablers are connected and work collaboratively for a Play approach​
Key stakeholders and enablers have the understanding of the value of Play​
Key stakeholders and enablers are well connected to and knowledgeable about Play​
Influencers understand and value the benefits of Play​
National, regional and local enablers have improved alignment for a Play approach​
Enablers identify and address barriers to access​
Key stakeholders and enablers are respected and credible​
Key stakeholders are connected and collaborate via a cross government collaborative play approach
Influencers provide tamariki with the time, permission, and place to Play​
Enablers provide tamariki with the time, permission, and place to Play​
Key stakeholders and enablers advocate effectively for the cross government play approach​
Key stakeholders action key Play actions in relation to the National PA and Play Plan *​
Organisations have effective systems in place to engage, educate and support rangatahi, influencers, other organisations and key stakeholders​
Organisations understand the value of Active Recreation​
Organisations have staff development programmes​
Organisations provide quality training and support for providers across sector​
Rangatahi have input into the design and delivery of opportunities​
Key stakeholders and organisations are well connected to and knowledgeable about the Active Recreation sector​
Key stakeholders and organisations have the knowledge and understanding of the value of Active Recreation​
Rangatahi understand and value the benefits of Active Recreation​
Organisations identify and address psychosocial barriers to participate in Active Recreation​
Influencers understand and value the benefits of Active Recreation​
There are a diverse range of capable providers of Active Recreation​
Physical and logistical barriers to participate in Active Recreation are identified and addressed​
Active Recreation opportunities are well promoted​
Key stakeholders and organisations are respected and credible​
Rangatahi have the motivation, knowledge, skills, confidence, and competence to participate in Active Recreation opportunities​
Influencers participate with, encourage and provide support to rangatahi​
There is a wide range of quality Active Recreation opportunities that meet the needs of rangatahi​
Access to Active Recreation opportunities is improved for rangatahi​
Key stakeholders and organisations advocate effectively for Active Recreation​
NSOs, NDOs, RSTs have effective coach development leadership personnel in place​
NSOs, RSOs, NDOs and RSTs have a network of skilled coach developers working with their coaches​
Coaches engage in their own development and adopt a participant-focused approach​
Parents have improved awareness and understanding of Balance is Better principles and the Value of Sport​
National, regional and local systems and structures for youth sport are improved and aligned​
There is a diverse range of capable providers of sport​
Barriers to participate in Sport are identified and addressed​
Key stakeholders are respected and credible and promote the Balance is Better principles​
Coaches provide better quality support to rangatahi in sport​
Parents provide better quality support to rangatahi in sport​
There is a wide range of quality sport opportunities that meets the needs of rangatahi​
Access to sport opportunities is improved for rangatahi​
Society advocates for sport and the Balance is Better principles​
Organisations allocate time and resource to coach development​
NSOs and NDOs have in place an effective Coach Developer Training (CDT) plan, coach development framework and annual delivery plan that align with the NZ Coaching Strategy​
RSTs have in place coach developer training programmes that aligns with the Sport NZ CDT programme​
Organisations provide quality development opportunities for coaches at all levels ​
Organisations have effective systems in place at national, regional and local levels to engage, educate and support parents​
Organisations understand, connect and collaborate around Balance is Better principles​
Competition structures and pathways are developed through a participant-centred approach​
NSOs, NDOs and RSTs provide quality Sport Development Leader training and wider support for providers across the sector​
Organisations are connected and working collaboratively around Balance is Better principles​
Key stakeholders have the knowledge and understanding of sport and the Balance is Better principles​
There is improved quality of support for teachers​
School leaders recognise the value of PE​
Sufficient resources are available to deliver quality PE (human, financial, time)​
Agencies who influence schools and the education system are connected and work collaboratively ​
Teachers have the confidence, skills and knowledge to teach PE well​
Schools prioritise and support regular provision of PE​
Education agencies and providers understand the value of PE​
Better quality PE is delivered​
A wide range of quality PE opportunities are available to meet the needs of tamariki​
Education agencies and providers are leading and advocating for PE within strategy and decision making​
